<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(c)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Use of Estimates&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>The preparation of financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally
accepted in the United States of America ("GAAP") requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the financial statements and accompanying notes. Actual
results could differ from those estimates. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under
fresh-start reporting, the Company's asset values were remeasured using fair value, which was allocated using the purchase method of accounting in conformity with SFAS&nbsp;141.
In addition, fresh-start reporting also requires that all liabilities, other than deferred taxes, should be stated at fair value, or at the present values of the amounts to be paid using appropriate
market interest rates. Deferred taxes are determined in conformity with SFAS&nbsp;109. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Estimates
of the fair value of assets and liabilities were determined based on the Company's best estimates as discussed in Note&nbsp;1, "Voluntary Reorganization Under
Chapter&nbsp;11&#151;Fresh-Start Reporting," above. The Company also estimates fair value of its financial instruments and its reporting units and indefinite-lived intangible assets for
testing impairment of indefinite-lived intangible assets, including goodwill. These estimates and assumptions are inherently subject to significant uncertainties and contingencies beyond the control
of the Company. Accordingly, the Company cannot provide assurance that the estimates, assumptions, and values reflected in the valuations will be realized, and actual results could vary materially. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(d)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Airline Revenues&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>The value of unused passenger tickets and miscellaneous charge orders ("MCO's") are included
in current liabilities as advance ticket sales. United records passenger ticket sales and tickets sold by other airlines for use on United as operating revenues when the transportation is provided or
when the ticket expires. Tickets sold by other airlines are recorded at the estimated values to be billed to the other airlines. Non-refundable tickets generally expire on the date of the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>90</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=90,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=1027341,FOLIO='90',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]FU42801A.;33',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_fu42801_1_91"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(2) Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>intended
flight, unless the date is extended by notification from the customer on or before the intended flight date. Fees charged in association with changes or extensions to nonrefundable tickets
are recorded as passenger revenue at the time the fee is incurred. Change fees related to non-refundable tickets are considered a separate transaction from the air transportation because
they represent a charge for the Company's additional service to modify a previous order. Therefore, the pricing of the change fee and the initial customer order are separately determined and represent
distinct earnings processes. Refundable tickets expire after one year. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MCO's
can be either exchanged for a passenger ticket or refunded after issuance. United also records an estimate of MCO's that will not be exchanged or refunded as revenue ratably over
the validity period based on historical results. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;United
records an estimate of tickets that have been used, but not recorded as revenue due to system processing errors, as revenue in the month of sale based on historical results. Due
to complex industry pricing structures, refund and exchange policies, and interline agreements with other airlines, certain amounts are recognized as revenue using estimates both as to the timing of
recognition and the amount of revenue to be recognized. These estimates are based on the evaluation of actual historical results. United recognizes cargo and mail revenue as service is provided. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(e)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Cash and Cash Equivalents, Short-Term Investments, Restricted Cash&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Cash in excess of operating
requirements is invested in short-term, highly liquid, income-producing investments. Investments with a maturity of three months or less on their acquisition date are classified as cash
and cash equivalents. Other investments are classified as short-term investments. Investments classified as held-to-maturity are stated at amortized cost, which
approximates market due to their short-term maturities. Investments in debt securities classified as available-for-sale are stated at fair value. The gains or
losses from sales of available-for-sale securities are included in interest income. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2007, UAL's and United's investments in debt securities classified as held-to-maturity included $1.3&nbsp;billion and
$1.2&nbsp;billion, respectively, recorded in cash and cash equivalents and $2.3&nbsp;billion recorded in short-term investments for both UAL and United. At December&nbsp;31, 2006,
UAL and United both had investments in debt securities classified as held-to-maturity of $3.8&nbsp;billion and recorded in cash
and cash equivalents and $312&nbsp;million and $308&nbsp;million, respectively, recorded in short-term investments. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Short-term
and long-term restricted cash in the Company's </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Statements of Consolidated Financial Position</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> represents
security for workers' compensation obligations, security deposits for airport leases and reserves with institutions that process our credit card ticket sales. Financial and other institutions with
which the Company conducts its business may require additional levels of security deposits or reserve holdbacks. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
Note&nbsp;7, "Investments," for information related to the Company's investments in non-current debt securities. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(f)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Aircraft Fuel, Spare Parts and Supplies&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>The Company records fuel, maintenance, operating supplies, and
aircraft spare parts at cost when acquired, and provides an obsolescence allowance for aircraft spare parts. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(g)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Operating Property and Equipment&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Owned operating property and equipment, and equipment under capital leases,
were stated at fair value as of February&nbsp;1, 2006. The Company records additions </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>91</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=91,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=243000,FOLIO='91',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]FU42801A.;33',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_fu42801_1_92"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(2) Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>to
owned operating property and equipment at cost when acquired. Property under capital leases, and the related obligation for future lease payments, is recorded at an amount equal to the initial
present value of those lease payments. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation
and amortization of owned depreciable assets is based on the straight-line method over the assets' estimated service lives. Leasehold improvements are amortized
over the remaining term of the lease, including estimated facility renewal options when renewal is reasonably assured at key airports, or the estimated service life of the related asset, whichever is
less. Aircraft are depreciated to estimated salvage values, generally over lives of 27 to 30&nbsp;years; buildings are depreciated over lives of 25 to 45&nbsp;years; and other property and
equipment are depreciated over lives of 4 to 15&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Properties
under capital leases are amortized on the straight-line method over the life of the lease or, in the case of certain aircraft, over their estimated service lives.
Lease terms are 5 to 17&nbsp;years for aircraft and 40&nbsp;years for buildings. Amortization of capital leases is included in depreciation and amortization expense. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Maintenance
and repairs, including the cost of minor replacements, are charged to maintenance expense as incurred, except for costs incurred under our
power-by-the-hour engine maintenance agreements, which are expensed based upon the number of hours flown. Costs of additions to and renewals of units of property
are capitalized as property and equipment additions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(h)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Mileage Plus Awards&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>As a result of the adoption of fresh-start reporting, the Mileage Plus frequent flyer
obligation was revalued at the Effective Date to reflect the estimated fair value of miles to be redeemed in the future. Outstanding miles earned by flying United or its partner carriers were revalued
using a weighted-average per-mile equivalent ticket value, taking into account such factors as historical redemption patterns, differing classes of service and domestic and international
ticket itineraries, which can be reflected in awards chosen by Mileage Plus members. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Successor Company also elected to change its accounting policy as of the Effective Date from an incremental cost basis to a deferred revenue model, to measure its obligation for
miles to be redeemed based upon the equivalent ticket value of similar fares on United or amounts paid to Star Alliance partners, as applicable. Effective December&nbsp;31, 2007, United's policy for
customer accounts which are inactive for a period of 18 consecutive months is to cancel all miles contained in those accounts at the end of the 18&nbsp;month period of inactivity. The Company
recognizes revenue from the expiration of miles in such deactivated accounts by amortizing such expiration over the 18&nbsp;month expiration period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior
to December&nbsp;31, 2007, the expiration period was 36&nbsp;months and revenue from expiration was amortized over the 36&nbsp;month expiration period. This change in the
expiration period provided a benefit to United's operating revenues of $246&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007. The pre-tax diluted per share benefit to UAL was
approximately $1.60 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007. Additional future changes to program rules and program redemption opportunities can significantly alter customer behavior from
historical patterns, which may result in material changes to the deferred revenue balance, as well as passenger revenues. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
Note&nbsp;18, "Advanced Purchase of Miles," for additional information related to the Mileage Plus program. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>92</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=92,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=804128,FOLIO='92',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]FU42801A.;33',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_fu42801_1_93"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(2) Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(i)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Deferred Gains&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Gains on aircraft sale and leaseback transactions are deferred and amortized over the terms of
the related leases as a reduction of aircraft rent expense. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(j)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>United Express&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>United has agreements under which independent regional carriers, flying under the United
Express name, connect passengers to other United Express and/or United flights (the latter of which we also refer to as "mainline" operations, to distinguish them from United Express regional
operations). The vast majority of United Express flights are operated under capacity agreements, while a relatively smaller number are operated under prorate agreements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;United
Express operating revenues and expenses are classified as "Passenger&#151;Regional Affiliates" and "Regional affiliates," respectively, in the </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Statements of Consolidated Operations</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, the latter includes
both allocated and direct costs. Direct costs represent expenses that are specifically and
exclusively related to United Express flying activities, such as capacity agreement payments, commissions, booking fees, fuel expenses and dedicated staffing. The capacity agreement payments are based
on specific rates for various operating expenses of the United Express carriers, such as crew expenses, maintenance and aircraft ownership, some of which are multiplied by specific operating
statistics (e.g.,&nbsp;block hours, departures) while others are fixed per month. Allocated costs represent United Express's portion of shared expenses and include charges for items such as airport
operating costs, reservation-related costs, credit card discount fees and facility rents. For each of these expense categories, the Company estimates United Express's portion of total expense and
allocates the applicable portion of expense to the United Express carrier. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;United
has the right to exclusively operate and direct the operations of these aircraft, and accordingly the minimum future lease payments for these aircraft are included in the
Company's lease obligations. See Note&nbsp;10, "Segment Information" and Note&nbsp;16, "Lease Obligations," for additional information related to United Express. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company recognizes revenue as flown on a net basis for flights on United Express covered by prorate agreements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;United
has call options on 152 regional jet aircraft currently being operated by certain United Express carriers. At December&nbsp;31, 2007, none of the call options were exercisable
because none of the required conditions to make an option exercisable by the Company were met. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(k)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Advertising&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Advertising costs, which are included in other operating expenses, are expensed as incurred. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(l)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Intangibles&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Goodwill represents the excess of the reorganization value of the Successor Company over the fair
value of net tangible assets and identifiable intangible assets and liabilities resulting from the application of SOP&nbsp;90-7. Indefinite-lived intangible assets are not amortized but
are reviewed for impairment annually or more frequently if events or circumstances indicate that the asset may be impaired. The Mileage Plus customer database is amortized on an accelerated basis
utilizing cash flows correlating to the expected attrition rate of the Mileage Plus database. The other customer relationships, which are included in "Contracts," are amortized in a manner consistent
with the timing and amount of revenues that the Company expects to generate from these customer relationships. All other definite-lived intangible assets are amortized on a straight-line
basis over the estimated lives of the related assets. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>93</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=93,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=856041,FOLIO='93',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]FU42801A.;33',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_fu42801_1_94"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(2) Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (Continued) </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;142, Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets ("SFAS&nbsp;142"), the Company applies a fair value-based impairment
test to the net book value of goodwill and indefinite-lived intangible assets on an annual basis as of October&nbsp;1, or on an interim basis whenever a triggering event occurs. SFAS&nbsp;142
requires that a two-step impairment test be performed on goodwill. In the first step, the Company compares the fair value of each reporting unit to its carrying value. If the fair value of
a reporting unit exceeds the carrying value of the net assets of the reporting unit, goodwill is not impaired and the Company is not required to perform further testing. If the carrying value of the
net assets of a reporting unit exceeds the fair value of the reporting unit, then the Company must perform the second step to determine the implied fair value of the goodwill and compare it to the
carrying value of the goodwill. If the carrying value of goodwill exceeds its implied fair value, then the Company must record an impairment charge equal to such difference. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company assesses the fair value of its reporting units considering both the market and income approaches. Under the market approach, fair value is based on a comparison of similar
publicly traded companies. Under the income approach, fair value is based on the present value of estimated future cash flows. The income approach is dependent on a number of assumptions including
estimates of future capacity, passenger yield, traffic, operating costs including jet fuel prices, appropriate discount rates and other relevant assumptions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No
impairments of goodwill or indefinite-lived assets have been identified since the Effective Date. See Note&nbsp;8, "Intangibles" for additional information. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(m)&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Measurement of Impairments&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>In accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;144, </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived
Assets</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> and SFAS&nbsp;142, the Company evaluates the carrying value of
long-lived assets and intangible assets subject to amortization whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that an impairment may exist. An impairment charge is recognized when
the asset's carrying value exceeds its net undiscounted future cash flows and its fair market value. The amount of the charge is the difference between the asset's carrying value and fair market
value. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(n)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Share-Based Compensation&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>The Company adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;123
(Revised 2004), </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Share-Based Payment</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> ("SFAS&nbsp;123R") effective January&nbsp;1, 2006. This pronouncement requires companies to measure the cost of
employee services received in exchange for an award of equity instruments based on the grant-date fair value of the award. The resulting cost is recognized over the period during which an
employee is required to provide service in exchange for the award, usually the vesting period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Before
the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;123R, the Company accounted for these plans under Accounting Principles Board Opinion No.&nbsp;25, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Stock
Issued to Employees,</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> ("APB&nbsp;25") and disclosed the pro forma compensation expense as required under Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;123, </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Stock Based Compensation,
</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> ("SFAS&nbsp;123"). No stock-based employee compensation cost for stock options is reflected in the Company's
financial statements for 2005, as all options granted had an exercise price equal to the market value of the underlying common stock on the date of grant. If compensation cost for stock-based employee
compensation plans had been determined using the fair value recognition provisions of SFAS&nbsp;123, the Company's 2005 net loss and loss per share would have increased by $4&nbsp;million and four
cents, respectively. See Note&nbsp;5, "Share-Based Compensation Plans," for additional information. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>94</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=94,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=949058,FOLIO='94',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]FU42801A.;33',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_fu42801_1_95"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(2) Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(o)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Ticket Taxes&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>Certain governmental taxes are imposed on United's ticket sales through a fee included in ticket
prices. United collects these fees and remits them to the appropriate government agency. These fees are recorded on a net basis (excluded from operating revenues). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(p)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>New Accounting Pronouncements&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>In September&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued Statement of Financial Accounting
Standards No.&nbsp;157, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Fair Value Measurements</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> ("SFAS&nbsp;157"), which defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value, and
expands disclosure about fair value measurements. SFAS&nbsp;157 does not require any new fair value measurements; rather it specifies valuation methods and disclosures to be applied when fair value
measurements are required under existing or future accounting pronouncements. As originally issued, SFAS&nbsp;157 is effective for fiscal years beginning January&nbsp;1, 2008. The Company does not
expect the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;157 with respect to its financial assets and financial liabilities to have a material impact on its results of operations or financial position. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
February&nbsp;2008, the FASB issued FASB Staff Position ("FSP") No. FAS&nbsp;157-b. This FSP&nbsp;delayed the effective date of SFAS&nbsp;157 for all nonfinancial
assets and nonfinancial liabilities, except those that are recognized or disclosed at fair value in the financial statements on a recurring basis, until periods beginning January&nbsp;1, 2009. The
Company is currently evaluating the impact of SFAS&nbsp;157 on the reporting and disclosure of its nonfinancial assets and nonfinancial liabilities. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
February&nbsp;2007, the FASB issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;159, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>The Fair Value Option for Financial Assets and Financial
Liabilities Including an amendment of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;115</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> ("SFAS&nbsp;159"). This statement permits entities to choose to measure many financial instruments and
certain other items at fair value that are not currently required to be measured at fair value. The objective of SFAS&nbsp;159 is to improve financial reporting by providing entities with the
opportunity to mitigate volatility in reported earnings caused by measuring related assets and liabilities differently without having to apply complex hedge accounting provisions. SFAS&nbsp;159 also
establishes presentation and disclosure requirements designed to facilitate comparisons between entities that choose different measurement attributes for similar types of assets and liabilities. This
statement does not affect any existing accounting literature that requires certain assets and liabilities to be carried at fair value. This statement is effective for the Company as of
January&nbsp;1, 2008. The Company did not elect to apply the provisions of SFAS&nbsp;159 to any of its existing financial assets or financial liabilities at January&nbsp;1, 2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2007, the FASB issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;141 (revised 2007), </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Business Combinations</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>
("SFAS&nbsp;141R"). This statement replaces Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;141, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Business Combinations.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> SFAS&nbsp;141R
retains the fundamental requirements in Statement No.&nbsp;141 that the acquisition method of accounting be used for all business combinations and for an acquirer to be identified for each business
combination. In addition, SFAS&nbsp;141R provides new guidance intended to improve reporting by creating greater consistency in the accounting and financial reporting of business combinations,
resulting in more complete, comparable, and relevant information for investors and other users of financial statements. SFAS&nbsp;141R is effective for the Company for any business combinations with
an acquisition date on or after January&nbsp;1, 2009. The Company will apply the provisions of SFAS&nbsp;141R to any business combinations within the scope of SFAS&nbsp;141R after its effective
date. In accordance with the provisions of SFAS&nbsp;141R that amended SFAS&nbsp;109, beginning January&nbsp;1, 2009, the Company will be required to recognize any changes in the valuation
allowance for deferred tax assets, which was established as part of fresh-start reporting, to be recognized as an adjustment to income tax expense. This reflects a change from current practice which </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>95</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=95,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=948975,FOLIO='95',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]FU42801A.;33',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_fu42801_1_96"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(2) Summary of Significant Accounting Policies (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>requires
changes in the valuation allowance to first reduce goodwill to zero and then to reduce intangible assets to zero. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2007, the FASB issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;160, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Noncontrolling Interests in Consolidated Financial
Statements&#151;an amendment of ARB No.&nbsp;51</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> ("SFAS&nbsp;160"). This statement amends Accounting Research Bulletin&nbsp;51, "Consolidated Financial Statements,"
to establish accounting and reporting standards for the noncontrolling interest (also known as minority interest) in a subsidiary and for the deconsolidation of a subsidiary. SFAS&nbsp;160 is
effective for the Company for periods beginning January&nbsp;1, 2009. The Company is currently evaluating the impact of SFAS&nbsp;160 on its consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2006, the Company adopted FASB Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;158, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Employers' Accounting for Defined Benefit Pension and Other
Postretirement Plans&#151;an amendment of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;87, 88, 106 and 132R</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> ("SFAS&nbsp;158"). </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;(q)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Income Tax Contingencies&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>UAL and United have recorded reserves for taxes and associated interest that may
become payable in future years as a result of audits by tax authorities. Certain of these reserves are for uncertain income tax positions taken on income tax returns which are accounted for in
accordance with FIN&nbsp;48, effective January&nbsp;1, 2007. Although management believes that the positions taken on previously filed tax returns are reasonable, UAL and United nevertheless have
established tax and interest reserves in recognition that various taxing authorities may challenge certain of the positions taken by the Company, potentially resulting in additional liabilities for
taxes and interest. The Company's tax contingency reserves are reviewed periodically and are adjusted as events occur that affect its estimates, such as the availability of new information, the
lapsing of applicable statutes of limitations, the conclusion of tax audits, the measurement of additional estimated liability based on current calculations, the identification of new tax
contingencies, the release of administrative tax guidance affecting its estimates of tax liabilities, or the rendering of relevant court decisions. See Note&nbsp;6, "Income Taxes," for further
information related to uncertain income tax positions and the adoption of FIN&nbsp;48. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(3) UAL Common Stockholders' Equity  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As a result of the Plan of Reorganization becoming effective on February&nbsp;1, 2006, the then-outstanding equity securities as well as the shares
held in treasury of Predecessor UAL were canceled. New UAL common stock began trading on the NASDAQ market on February&nbsp;2, 2006 under the symbol "UAUA." In accordance with the Plan of
Reorganization, Successor UAL established the equity structure in the table below upon emergence and, on February&nbsp;2, 2006, began distributing portions of the shares of new common stock to
certain general unsecured creditors and employees and certain management employees and non-employee directors. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2007, 2.8&nbsp;million of the initial 115&nbsp;million shares authorized remain to be distributed to employees and
holders of previously allowed claims and disputed claims that are pending final resolution. All treasury shares were MEIP shares acquired either for tax withholding obligations or as consideration
under an employment agreement. Forfeited MEIP shares or MEIP shares that are settled for cash or stock are automatically available again for issuance under the MEIP. See Note&nbsp;5, "Share-Based
Compensation Plans" for additional information related to the remaining grants available to be awarded under the MEIP and DEIP and outstanding option awards, neither of which are included in
outstanding shares above. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(4) UAL Per Share Amounts  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;128, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Earnings per Share</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>
("SFAS&nbsp;128"), basic per share amounts were computed by dividing earnings (loss) available to common stockholders by the weighted-average number of shares of UAL common stock outstanding.
Approximately 2.8&nbsp;million and 6.7&nbsp;million UAL shares remaining to be issued to unsecured creditors and employees under the Plan of Reorganization are included in outstanding basic shares
for 2007 and the eleven month period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, respectively, as the necessary conditions for issuance have been satisfied. UAL's $500&nbsp;million of 6% senior notes are
callable at any time at 100% of par value, and can be redeemed with either cash or UAL common stock at UAL's option. These notes </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>97</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(5) Share-Based Compensation Plans  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Compensation expense associated with the UAL share-based compensation plans has been pushed down to United. See Note&nbsp;2(n), "Summary of Significant
Accounting Policies&#151;Share-Based </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>98</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>

<A NAME="page_fw42801_1_99"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(5) Share-Based Compensation Plans (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Compensation,"
for information regarding the Company's adoption of SFAS&nbsp;123R effective January&nbsp;1, 2006 and pro forma compensation expense for 2005. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Predecessor Company&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>As of January&nbsp;31, 2006, a total of 9&nbsp;million stock options were outstanding. The Company did
not issue any stock-based awards during 2005. Under the Company's Plan of Reorganization, these stock options were canceled on the Effective Date. No material share-based compensation expense was
incurred as a result of these outstanding options for the month of January&nbsp;2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT><FONT
SIZE=2><B><I>Successor Company&#151;</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>As part of the Plan of Reorganization and as described in more detail below, the Bankruptcy Court approved
UAL's share-based compensation plans known as the MEIP and the DEIP which became effective on February&nbsp;1, 2006. The following table summarizes the number of awards authorized, issued and
available for future grants under each plan as of December&nbsp;31, 2007: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The unrecognized compensation cost related to unvested awards at December&nbsp;31, 2007 was $41&nbsp;million which is expected to be
recognized over a weighted-average period of 2.2&nbsp;years. During the second quarter of 2006, the Company revised its initial estimated award forfeiture rate of 7.5% to 15% based upon actual
attrition. As a result, the share-based compensation expense was reduced by approximately $7&nbsp;million for the eleven month period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Management Equity Incentive Plan ("MEIP").</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Human Resources Subcommittee of the UAL Board of Directors (the "HR
Subcommittee") is authorized under the plan to grant equity-based and other performance-based awards ("Award(s)") to executive officers and other key management employees of the Company and its
subsidiaries. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;All
executive officers and other key management employees of the Company and its subsidiaries are eligible to become participants in the MEIP. The HR Subcommittee will select from time
to time, from among all eligible individuals, the persons who will be granted an Award. The MEIP authorizes </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>99</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=99,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=1036616,FOLIO='99',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]FW42801A.;30',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='28-FEB-2008;15:47' -->
<A NAME="page_fw42801_1_100"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(5) Share-Based Compensation Plans (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>the
HR Subcommittee to grant any of a variety of incentive Awards to participants, including the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>stock
options, including both tax qualified and non-qualified options,
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>stock
appreciation rights, which provide the participant the right to receive the excess (if any) of the fair market value of a specified number of shares of common stock at
the time of exercise over the grant price of the stock appreciation right,
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>stock
awards to be granted at no cost to the participant, including grants in the form of (i)&nbsp;an immediate transfer of shares which are subject to forfeiture and
certain transfer restrictions ("Restricted Stock"); and (ii)&nbsp;an immediate transfer of shares which are not subject to forfeiture or a deferred transfer of shares if and when the conditions
specified by the HR Subcommittee are met ("Unrestricted Stock"), and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>performance-based
awards, in which the HR Subcommittee may grant a stock award that will entitle the holder to receive a specified number of shares of common stock, or the
cash value thereof, if certain performance goals are met. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
shares may be issued from authorized and unissued shares of UAL common stock or from UAL's treasury stock. The exercise price for each underlying share of UAL common stock under all
options and stock appreciation rights awarded under the MEIP will not be less than the fair market value of a share of common stock on the date of grant or as otherwise determined by the HR
Subcommittee. Each instrument granted under the MEIP will generally expire 10&nbsp;years after its date of grant. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
table below summarizes stock option activity pursuant to UAL's MEIP stock options for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007: </FONT></P>

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>The
aggregate intrinsic value of shares exercised in 2006 was $3&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Options
represent the number of vested options at December&nbsp;31, 2007. Aggregate intrinsic value is based only on vested options that have an exercise price less than the UAUA
stock price at December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></DD></DL>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value of options was determined at the grant date using a Black-Scholes option pricing model, which requires the Company to make several
assumptions. The risk-free interest rate is based on the U.S. Treasury yield curve in effect for the expected term of the option at the time of grant. The dividend yield on UAL's common
stock was assumed to be zero since UAL did not have any plans to pay dividends at the time of the option grants. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
volatility assumptions were based upon historical volatilities of comparable airlines whose shares are traded using daily stock price returns equivalent to the contractual term of
the option. Since the new UAL common stock only began trading in February&nbsp;2006, the historical volatility data for UAL was not considered adequate to determine expected volatility. The Company
did consider implied volatility data for both UAL and comparable airlines, using current exchange-traded options. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
expected life of the options was determined based upon a simplified assumption that the option will be exercised evenly from vesting to expiration under the transitional guidance of
Staff Accounting Bulletin No.&nbsp;107, Topic 14, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Share-Based Payments</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. The stock options typically vest over a four year period, except for awards to
retirement-eligible employees, which are considered vested at the grant date. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under
SFAS&nbsp;123R, the fair value of the Restricted Stock awards was based upon the volume weighted-average share price on the date of grant. These awards generally vest over four
years. However, if an employee is retirement eligible at the grant date, the award is immediately vested. In addition, if an employee will become retirement eligible within four years of the grant
date, the award will vest over the remaining period to retirement eligibility. Approximately 1.7&nbsp;million of the 2.0&nbsp;million nonvested restricted stock awards at December&nbsp;31, 2007
are expected to vest. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
table below summarizes Restricted Stock activity for the twelve months ended December&nbsp;31, 2007: </FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=101,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=78887,FOLIO='101',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]FW42801A.;30',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='28-FEB-2008;15:47' -->
<A NAME="page_fw42801_1_102"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(5) Share-Based Compensation Plans (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value of restricted shares vested in 2007 was $28&nbsp;million. The weighted-average grant date price of shares granted in 2006 was
$36.78. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Director Equity Incentive Plan ("DEIP").</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Nominating/Governance Committee of the UAL Board of Directors (the "Governance
Committee") is authorized to grant equity-based awards to non-employee directors of the Company under the plan. The DEIP authorizes the Governance Committee to grant any of a variety of
incentive awards to participants, including the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>non-qualified
stock options,
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>stock
appreciation rights, which provide the participant the right to receive the excess (if any) of the fair market value of a specified number of shares of common stock at
the time of exercise over the grant price of the stock appreciation right,
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>stock
awards to be granted at no cost to the participant, including grants in the form of Restricted Stock and Unrestricted Stock,
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>annual
compensation in the form of credits to a participant's share account established under the DEIP, and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>UAL
common stock in lieu of receipt of all or any portion of cash amounts payable by UAL to a participant including retainer fees, board attendance fees and committee fees
(but excluding expense reimbursements and similar items). </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
shares may be issued from authorized and unissued shares of UAL common stock or from UAL's treasury stock. The exercise price for each underlying share of UAL common stock under all
options and stock appreciation rights awarded under the DEIP will not be less than the fair market value of a share of common stock on the date of grant. Each instrument granted under the DEIP will
generally expire 10&nbsp;years after its date of grant. The 100,000 unrestricted shares issued under the DEIP in the eleven month period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 immediately vested on their
respective grant dates. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(6) Income Taxes  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;United and its domestic consolidated subsidiaries, file a consolidated federal income tax return with UAL. Under an intercompany tax allocation policy, United and
its subsidiaries compute, record and pay UAL for their own tax liability as if they were separate companies filing separate returns. In
determining their own tax liabilities, United and each of its subsidiaries take into account all tax credits or benefits generated and utilized as separate companies, and they are compensated for the
aforementioned tax benefits only if they would be able to use those benefits on a separate company basis. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2007, the Company's current regular taxable income was completely absorbed by utilization of its net operating loss ("NOL") carry forward; however, it did incur an alternative minimum
tax ("AMT") liability of $6&nbsp;million, as indicated in the table below. In 2006 and 2005, the Company incurred both a regular tax loss and an AMT loss. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>102</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<TD COLSPAN=2 style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Net deferred tax liability</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>(560</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>)</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>(566</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>)</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>(483</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>)</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="7%" ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>(482</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>)</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD COLSPAN=2 style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="RIGHT" style="font-family:times;"><HR NOSHADE SIZE=4></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</TR>
</TABLE>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The federal and state NOL carry forwards relate to prior years' NOLs which may be carried forward to reduce the tax liabilities of future years.
This tax benefit is mostly attributable to federal pre-tax NOL carry forwards of $6.6&nbsp;billion. If not utilized, the federal tax benefits of $1.0&nbsp;billion expire </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>104</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=104,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=704037,FOLIO='104',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]FW42801A.;30',USER='ABLIJDE',CD='28-FEB-2008;15:47' -->
<A NAME="page_fw42801_1_105"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(6) Income Taxes (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>in
2022, $0.4&nbsp;billion expire in 2023, $0.5&nbsp;billion expire in 2024 and $0.4&nbsp;billion expire in 2025. In addition, the state tax benefit of $156&nbsp;million, if not utilized,
expires over a five to twenty year period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
this time, the Company does not believe that the limitations imposed by the Internal Revenue Code on the usage of the NOL carry forward and other tax attributes following an ownership
change will have an effect on the Company. Therefore, the Company does not believe its exit from bankruptcy has had any material impact on the utilization of its remaining NOL carry forward and other
tax attributes. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
ultimate realization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income (including the reversals of deferred tax liabilities) during the periods in
which those temporary differences will become deductible. The Company's management assesses the realizability of its deferred tax assets, and records a valuation allowance for the deferred tax assets
when it is more likely than not that a portion, or all of the deferred tax assets, will not be realized. As a result, the Company has a valuation allowance against its deferred tax assets as of
December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, to reflect management's assessment regarding the realizability of those assets. The Company expects to continue to maintain a valuation allowance on deferred tax
assets until other positive evidence is sufficient. The
current valuation allowance of $1,815&nbsp;million and $1,757&nbsp;million for UAL and United, respectively, if reversed in 2008 will be allocated to reduce goodwill and then other intangible
assets; if reversed in 2009 or later, it will be allocated to reduce income tax expense as discussed in Note&nbsp;2(p), "Summary of Significant Accounting Policies&#151;New Accounting
Pronouncements." </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to the deferred tax assets listed above, the Company has an $801&nbsp;million unrecorded tax benefit at December&nbsp;31, 2007 attributable to the difference between the
amount of the financial statement expense and the allowable tax deduction for UAL common stock issued to certain unsecured creditors and employees pursuant to the Plan of Reorganization. The Company
is accounting for this unrecorded tax benefit by analogy to SFAS&nbsp;123R which requires recognition of the tax benefit to be deferred until it is realized as a reduction of taxes payable. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
January&nbsp;1, 2007, we adopted the provisions of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Uncertainty in Income
Taxes</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> ("FIN&nbsp;48"). Our adoption of FIN&nbsp;48 resulted in a $24&nbsp;million increase in the liability for unrecognized tax benefits ("UTB") which was accounted for
as a $6&nbsp;million decrease in goodwill, a $2&nbsp;million increase in additional capital invested, and a $32&nbsp;million increase to deferred tax assets. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2007, our liability for uncertain tax positions was $35&nbsp;million. UTB of $19&nbsp;million would affect our effective tax rate if recognized. Excluding
amounts related to tax positions for which the ultimate deductibility is highly certain, there were no significant changes in the components of the liability in the twelve months ending
December&nbsp;31, 2007. Any change in the amount of unrecognized tax benefits within the next twelve months is not expected to result in a significant impact on the results of operations or the
financial position of the Company. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Included
in the balance at December&nbsp;31, 2007 is $16&nbsp;million of tax positions for which the ultimate deductibility is highly certain but for which there is uncertainty about
the timing of such deductibility. Because of the impact of deferred tax accounting, other than interest and penalties, the disallowance of the shorter deductibility period would not affect the
effective tax rate but would cause a reduction to the net operating losses available for utilization. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
record penalties and interest relating to uncertain tax positions in the other operating expense and interest expense line items, respectively, within our consolidated statement of
income. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>105</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our income tax returns for tax years after 2002 remain subject to examination by the Internal Revenue Service and state taxing jurisdictions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(7) Investments  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company had investments accounted for using the cost method of accounting of $5&nbsp;million and $91&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006,
respectively. The Company revalued its investments to their estimated fair values as of the Effective Date in accordance with SOP&nbsp;90-7. Since that time, there have been no
triggering events that required the Company to evaluate any of these investments for impairment. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the fourth quarter of 2007, United, along with certain other major air carriers, sold its interests in Aeronautical Radio,&nbsp;Inc. ("ARINC") to Radio Acquisition Corp., an
affiliate of The Carlyle Group. ARINC is a provider of transportation communications and systems engineering. The transaction generated proceeds of $128&nbsp;million and resulted in a
pre-tax gain of $41&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Investments
at December&nbsp;31, 2007 include $91&nbsp;million of the Company's previously issued EETC debt securities that the Company repurchased in 2007. These securities remain
outstanding and are classified as available-for-sale. An unrealized loss of $5&nbsp;million to record these securities at fair value has been recognized in other comprehensive income during 2007.
See Note&nbsp;12, "Debt Obligations," for additional information. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(8) Intangibles  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As discussed in Note&nbsp;10, "Segment Information," in 2006 the Company determined that it has two reporting segments that reflect the management of its
business: Mainline and United Express. See Note&nbsp;2(l), "Summary of Significant Accounting Policies&#151;Intangibles," for further information related to impairment testing. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>106</FONT></P>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company initially recorded goodwill of $2,756&nbsp;million upon its exit from bankruptcy. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007,
goodwill decreased by $423&nbsp;million due to a $414&nbsp;million reduction of the valuation allowance for the deferred tax assets established at fresh-start, $6&nbsp;million due to the
adoption of FIN&nbsp;48 and $3&nbsp;million due to a change in estimate of tax accruals existing at the Effective Date. During the eleven month period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, goodwill was
decreased by $62&nbsp;million due to Successor Company tax activity that impacted the deferred tax asset valuation allowance, and increased by $9&nbsp;million due to net adjustments to the fair
values of certain assets and liabilities. Total amortization expense recognized was $155&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, $1&nbsp;million for the one month period ended
January&nbsp;31, 2006 and $169&nbsp;million for the eleven month period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. The Company expects to record amortization expense of $92&nbsp;million,
$70&nbsp;million, $64&nbsp;million, $59&nbsp;million and $56&nbsp;million for 2008, 2009, 2010, 2011 and 2012, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Open Skies.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On April&nbsp;30, 2007, the U.S. government and the European Union ("EU") signed a
transatlantic aviation agreement to replace the existing bilateral arrangements between the U.S. Government and the 27 EU member states. The agreement is expected to become effective at the end of
March&nbsp;2008. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
agreement is based on the U.S. open skies model and authorizes U.S. airlines to operate between the United States and any point in the EU and beyond, free from government
restrictions on capacity, frequencies and scheduling and provides EU carriers with reciprocal rights in these U.S./EU markets. The agreement also authorizes all U.S. and EU carriers to operate
services between the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>107</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=107,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=605185,FOLIO='107',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]FY42801A.;55',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_fy42801_1_108"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(8) Intangibles (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>United
States and London Heathrow, thereby potentially adding new competition to United's Heathrow operation, although Heathrow is currently subject to both slot and facility constraints which may
practically limit the extent of new competition in the near term. This agreement does not provide for a reallocation of existing slots among carriers. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, United recorded an indefinite-lived intangible asset of $255&nbsp;million for its London Heathrow slots, based upon its estimation of the fair
value for those slots as of the adoption of fresh-start reporting on February&nbsp;1, 2006. United, however, determined at fresh-start that its rights relating to its actual route authorities to
Heathrow had a fair value of zero. The EU/U.S. open skies agreement is expected to directly impact the future value and expected lives of route authorities to Heathrow; however, there is no direct
impact from the open skies agreement on airport slot rights, including those at Heathrow. The open skies agreement is also expected to provide United an opportunity to secure antitrust immunity for
certain of its Star Alliance carrier relationships, and to provide United and other carriers with access to new markets in EU countries. In September&nbsp;2007, the DOT granted United and bmi
antitrust immunity. The immunity goes into effect at the same time as the open skies agreement between the U.S. and the EU in March of 2008. Because of the diverse nature of these potential impacts on
United's business, the overall future impact of the EU agreement on United's business in the EU region cannot be predicted with certainty. United has concluded that, in certain circumstances, the open
skies agreement could indirectly and adversely affect the fair value of its slot rights at Heathrow, and therefore has further concluded that the signing of the open skies agreement on
April&nbsp;30, 2007, constituted an indicator of impairment with respect to United's Heathrow slots intangible asset. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;United
performed annual impairment reviews of goodwill and indefinite lived intangible assets as of October&nbsp;1, 2007 and 2006 and determined that no impairment was indicated. In
addition, a 2007 interim impairment review was performed for the Heathrow slots intangible asset, and the Company concluded that no impairment was then indicated and that no change was then required
to the fresh-start assignment of an indefinite life to the Heathrow slots. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(9) Retirement and Postretirement Plans  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company maintains various retirement plans, both defined benefit (qualified and non-qualified) and defined contribution, which cover substantially
all employees. As discussed below, most of the Company's defined benefit plans were terminated and replaced with defined contribution plans as part of the bankruptcy reorganization. The Company also
provides certain health care benefits, primarily in the U.S., to retirees and eligible dependents, as well as certain life insurance benefits to certain retirees reflected as "Other Benefits" in the
tables below. The Company has reserved the right, subject to collective bargaining agreements, to modify or terminate the health care and life insurance benefits for both current and future retirees. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Upon
emergence from bankruptcy on February&nbsp;1, 2006, the Company completed a revaluation of the postretirement liabilities resulting in a reduction of the net accumulated benefit
obligation of approximately $28&nbsp;million. In accordance with SOP&nbsp;90-7 upon emergence, the Company also accelerated the recognition of net unrecognized actuarial gains and
losses, prior service costs and transition obligation pertaining to its foreign pension plans and postretirement plans, and recorded a reorganization expense thereon. The unrecognized costs as of
January&nbsp;31, 2006 that were recognized as part of fresh-start reporting are reported in the table below. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>108</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=108,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=1027044,FOLIO='108',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]FY42801A.;55',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_fy42801_1_109"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(9) Retirement and Postretirement Plans (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
April&nbsp;2005, United and the PBGC entered into a global settlement agreement which provided for the settlement and compromise of various disputes and controversies with respect
to the Company's domestic pension plans. In May&nbsp;2005, the Bankruptcy Court approved the settlement agreement, including modifications requested by certain creditors. The PBGC assumed
responsibility for the assets of the Ground Plan effective May&nbsp;23, 2005 (with a termination date of March&nbsp;11, 2005), the Flight Attendant and the MAPC Plans effective June&nbsp;30,
2005 and the Pilot Plan effective October&nbsp;26, 2005, and the Company has no further duties or rights with respect to these plans. In 2005, the Company recorded $640&nbsp;million in curtailment
charges related to these pension plans and reclassified $1.9&nbsp;billion of pension obligations to Liabilities subject to compromise. The Company recorded approximately $7.2&nbsp;billion of PBGC
allowable claims in Liabilities subject to compromise in accordance with the confirmed Plan of Reorganization. In addition, the Company recognized net settlement losses of approximately
$1.1&nbsp;billion in 2005 in accordance with SFAS&nbsp;88. See Note&nbsp;1, "Voluntary Reorganization Under Chapter&nbsp;11" for more information. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table sets forth the reconciliation of the beginning and ending balances of the benefit obligation and plan assets, the funded status and the amounts recognized in the </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Statements of Consolidated Financial
Position</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> for the defined benefit and other postretirement plans ("Other Benefits"): </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<A NAME="page_fy42801_1_110"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(9) Retirement and Postretirement Plans (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="100%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="BOTTOM">
<TH COLSPAN=17 ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>
<TH COLSPAN=2 ALIGN="LEFT" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT><BR></TH>
<TH WIDTH="1%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=1>&nbsp;</FONT></TH>

gains are $1&nbsp;million for pension plans and $17&nbsp;million for </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>110</FONT></P>

<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=110,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=152459,FOLIO='110',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]FY42801A.;55',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_fy42801_1_111"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(9) Retirement and Postretirement Plans (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>other
postretirement plans. At exit the Company elected not to apply the corridor approach for amortization of unrecognized amounts included in accumulated other comprehensive income. This policy may
result in more volatility in the amortization of these unrecognized amounts into net periodic pension cost. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following information relates to all pension plans with an accumulated benefit obligation and a projected benefit obligation in excess of plan assets: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The net periodic benefit cost included the following components: </FONT></P>

<A NAME="page_ga42801_1_113"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(9) Retirement and Postretirement Plans (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company believes that the long-term asset allocations on average will approximate the targeted allocations and regularly reviews
the actual asset allocations to periodically rebalance the investments to the targeted allocations when appropriate. The target asset allocations are established with the objective of achieving the
plans' expected return on assets without undue investment risk. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Expected
2008 contributions are $29&nbsp;million for the pension plans and $170&nbsp;million for the other postretirement benefit plans. The following benefit payments are expected
to be made in future years for the Company's retirement plans: </FONT></P>
