<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> Defined Contribution Plans  </B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In place of the domestic defined benefit pension plans that were terminated during bankruptcy, the Company enhanced its contributions to the defined contribution
plans for most employee groups. Contributions are based on matching percentages, years of service and/or eligible earnings. The Company's contribution percentages vary from 1 to 15% of eligible
earnings depending on the terms of each plan. The Company agreed to contribute to most of its defined contribution plans effective in June and July&nbsp;2005, although such contributions for 2005
were not funded until shortly after the Effective Date. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Effective
March&nbsp;1, 2006, an International Association of Machinists ("IAM") replacement plan was implemented. The IAM replacement plan is a multi-employer plan whereby the assets
contributed by the Company (based on hours worked) may be used to provide benefits to employees of other participating companies, since assets contributed by all participating companies are not
segregated or restricted to provide benefits specifically to employees of one participating company. In accordance with the applicable accounting for multi-employer plans, the Company would only
recognize a withdrawal obligation if it becomes probable it would withdraw from the plan. The Predecessor Company recorded expense from defined contribution plans of $16&nbsp;million for the month
of January&nbsp;2006 and $122&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. The Successor Company recognized $232&nbsp;million and $206&nbsp;million of expense for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2007 and the eleven months ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, respectively, for all of the Company's defined contribution employee retirement plans, of which $28&nbsp;million and
$21&nbsp;million, respectively, related to the IAM multi-employer plan. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(10) Segment Information  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Segments.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company manages its business by two reporting segments: Mainline and United Express.
The Company manages its business as an integrated network with assets deployed across various regions. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>113</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=113,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=163622,FOLIO='113',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]GA42801A.;34',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_ga42801_1_114"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(10) Segment Information (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
accounting policies for each of these reporting segments are the same as those described in Note&nbsp;2, "Summary of Significant Accounting Policies," except that segment financial
information has been prepared using a management approach which is consistent with how the Company internally disperses financial information for the purpose of making internal operating decisions.
The Company evaluates segment financial performance based on earnings before income taxes, special items, reorganization items, and gain on sale of investments. As discussed in the notes to the tables
below, the Company does not allocate corporate overhead expenses to its United Express segment. Certain selling and
operational costs are allocated to United Express. See Note&nbsp;2(j), "Summary of Significant Accounting Policies&#151;United Express" for additional information related to United Express
expenses. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table presents UAL segment information for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, the eleven month period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, the one month period ended
January&nbsp;31, 2006 and the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005: </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="1%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><BR>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>United
Express depreciation expense relates to assets used in United Express operations. This depreciation is included in Regional affiliates expense in the Company's </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Statements of Consolidated Operations</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Equity
earnings are part of the mainline segment. </FONT></DD></DL>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>United
Express depreciation expense relates to assets used in United Express operations. This depreciation is included in Regional affiliates expense in the Company's </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Statements of Consolidated Operations</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Equity
earnings are part of the mainline segment. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company does not allocate interest income or interest expense to the United Express segment in reports used to evaluate segment performance.
Therefore, all amounts classified as interest income and interest expense in the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Statements of Consolidated Operations</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> relate to the mainline segment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
accordance with SFAS&nbsp;142, on the Effective Date the Company allocated goodwill upon adoption of fresh-start reporting in a manner similar to how the amount of goodwill
recognized in a business combination is determined. This required the determination of the fair value of each reporting unit to calculate an estimated purchase price for such reporting unit. This
purchase price was then allocated to the individual assets and liabilities assumed to be related to that reporting unit. Any excess purchase price is the amount of goodwill assigned to that reporting
unit. To the extent that individual assets and liabilities could be assigned directly to specific reporting units, those assets and liabilities </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>115</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=115,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=4141,FOLIO='115',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]GA42801A.;34',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_ga42801_1_116"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(10) Segment Information (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>were
so assigned. As a result of this process, all of the Company's goodwill has been allocated to the Mainline segment. See Note&nbsp;8, "Intangibles," for further information related to goodwill. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company attributes revenue among the geographic areas based upon the origin and destination of each flight segment. United's operations
involve an insignificant level of dedicated revenue-producing assets in geographic regions as the overwhelming majority of the Company's revenue producing assets (primarily U.S. registered aircraft)
generally can be deployed in any of its geographic regions, as any given aircraft may be used in multiple geographic regions on any given day. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The 2006 and 2005 pension-related amounts represent the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;158 and the minimum pension liability under SFAS&nbsp;87,
respectively. During the initial adoption of SFAS&nbsp;158, the Company recorded deferred taxes on the portion of other comprehensive income associated with the Medicare Part&nbsp;D subsidiary. In
2007, the Company recomputed deferred taxes on the portion of the initial other comprehensive balance at the adoption date excluding the amount of comprehensive income attributable to the Medicare
Part&nbsp;D subsidiary. This adjustment of $40&nbsp;million is excluded from comprehensive income and is reported separately in the Company's </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Statements of Stockholders'
Equity</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(12) Debt Obligations  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2007, the Company prepaid and amended the credit facility and issued, repaid and repurchased various debt instruments, as discussed below. Previously during
2006, in accordance with the Plan of Reorganization, the Company issued new debt, entered into the credit facility, reinstated certain secured aircraft debt and entered into other debt agreements
negotiated during the bankruptcy process (including aircraft financings) in addition to repaying the DIP Financing in its entirety. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Long-term
debt amounts outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006 are shown below: </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>117</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=117,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=18542,FOLIO='117',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]GC42801A.;24',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_gc42801_1_118"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(12) Debt Obligations (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>2007 Financing Transactions  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Amended Credit Facility.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In February&nbsp;2007, the Company prepaid $972&nbsp;million of its credit facility debt (see
2006 Debt Transactions, below) and entered into an amended and restated revolving credit, term loan and guaranty agreement (the "Amended Credit Facility") that, among other things, reduced the size of
the facility from $3.0&nbsp;billion to $2.055&nbsp;billion, reduced the applicable interest rates, and provided for a more limited collateral package and a relaxation of certain restrictive
covenants. There were no prepayment penalties associated with this debt retirement. In addition, United also incurred financing costs of $10&nbsp;million of which $6&nbsp;million was expensed and
$4&nbsp;million was capitalized. The financing costs associated with the credit facility amendment and prepayment, which were expensed, are classified within interest expense. The Company expensed
approximately $17&nbsp;million of deferred financing costs which are related to the portion of the credit facility prepaid in February&nbsp;2007 and included in other assets on the
December&nbsp;31, 2006</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I> Statements of Consolidated Financial Position.  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, in December&nbsp;2007 the Company prepaid an additional $500&nbsp;million of the term loan under the Amended Credit Facility. In connection with
this prepayment, the Company expensed an additional
$6&nbsp;million of previously capitalized debt issuance costs. The Company also recognized a $2&nbsp;million credit to interest expense to recognize previously deferred interest rate swap gains. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
December&nbsp;2007 amendment enabled the Company to undertake certain shareholder initiatives. UAL's Board of Directors approved a special distribution of $2.15 per share to
holders of UAL common stock, or approximately $257&nbsp;million, which was paid on January&nbsp;23, 2008. The Company can undertake approximately $243&nbsp;million in additional shareholder
initiatives without any additional prepayment of the Amended Credit Facility. The amendment also provides that the Company can carry out further shareholder initiatives in an amount equal to future
term loan prepayments. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Amended Credit Facility provided for a total commitment of up to $2.055&nbsp;billion, comprised of two separate tranches: (i)&nbsp;a Tranche&nbsp;A consisting of
$255&nbsp;million revolving commitment available for Tranche&nbsp;A loans and standby letters of credit and (ii)&nbsp;a Tranche&nbsp;B consisting of a term loan commitment of
$1.8&nbsp;billion available at the time of closing. The Tranche&nbsp;A loans mature on February&nbsp;1, 2012, and the Tranche&nbsp;B loans mature on February&nbsp;1, 2014. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Borrowings
under the Amended Credit Facility bear interest at a floating rate, which, at the Company's option, can be either a base rate or a LIBOR rate, plus an applicable margin of
1.0% in the case of base rate loans, and 2.0% in the case of LIBOR loans. The Tranche&nbsp;B term loan requires regularly scheduled semi-annual payments of principal equal to
$9&nbsp;million. Interest is payable at least every three months. The Company may prepay some or all of the Tranche&nbsp;B loans from time to time, at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount
prepaid plus accrued and unpaid interest, if any, to the date of prepayment, but without penalty or premium. In addition, letters of credit issued under the credit facility as of December&nbsp;31,
2007 in an aggregate amount of $102&nbsp;million were subject to a fee at the rate of 2.0% per annum. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;United's
obligations under the Amended Credit Facility are unconditionally guaranteed by UAL Corporation and certain of its direct and indirect domestic subsidiaries, other than certain
immaterial subsidiaries (the "Guarantors"). On the closing date for the Amended Credit Facility, the obligations are secured by a security interest in the following tangible and intangible assets of
United and the Guarantors: (i)&nbsp;the Pacific (Narita, China and Hong Kong) and Atlantic (Heathrow) routes (the "Primary Routes") that United had as of February&nbsp;2, 2007, (ii)&nbsp;primary
foreign slots, primary domestic </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>118</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=118,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=346929,FOLIO='118',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]GC42801A.;24',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_gc42801_1_119"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(12) Debt Obligations (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>slots,
certain gate interests in domestic airport terminals and certain supporting route facilities, (iii)&nbsp;certain spare engines, (iv)&nbsp;certain quick engine change kits,
(v)&nbsp;certain owned real property and related fixtures, and (vi)&nbsp;certain flight simulators (the "Collateral"). After the closing date, and subject to certain conditions, United and the
Guarantors may grant a security interest in the following assets, in substitution for certain Collateral (which may be released from the lien in support of the Amended Credit Facility upon the
satisfaction of certain conditions): (a)&nbsp;certain aircraft, (b)&nbsp;certain spare parts, (c)&nbsp;certain ground handling equipment, and (d)&nbsp;accounts receivable. In addition, United
has the right to remove collateral pledged to the Amended Credit Facility as long as the minimum collateral ratio described in item&nbsp;(iii) below is achieved. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Amended Credit Facility contains covenants that in certain circumstances may limit the ability of United and the Guarantors to, among other things, incur or guarantee additional
indebtedness, create liens, pay dividends on or repurchase stock, make certain types of investments, enter into transactions with affiliates, sell assets or merge with other companies, modify
corporate documents or change lines of business. The Amended Credit Facility also requires compliance with the following financial covenants: (i)&nbsp;a minimum ratio of EBITDAR to the sum of cash
interest expense, aircraft rent and scheduled debt payments, (ii)&nbsp;a minimum unrestricted cash balance of $750&nbsp;million, and (iii)&nbsp;a minimum ratio of market value of collateral to
the sum of (a)&nbsp;the aggregate outstanding amount of the loans plus (b)&nbsp;the undrawn amount of outstanding letters of credit, plus (c)&nbsp;the unreimbursed amount of drawings under such
letters of credit and (d)&nbsp;the termination value of certain interest rate protection and hedging agreements with the Amended Credit Facility lenders and their affiliates, of 150% at any time, or
200% at any time following the release of Primary Routes having an appraised value in excess of $1&nbsp;billion (unless the Primary Routes are the only collateral then pledged). Failure to comply
with the Amended Credit Facility covenants could result in a default under the Amended Credit Facility unless the Company were to obtain a waiver of, or otherwise mitigate or cure, the default.
Additionally, the Amended Credit Facility contains a cross-default provision with respect to other credit arrangements that exceed $50&nbsp;million. A default could result in a termination of the
Amended Credit Facility and a requirement to accelerate repayment of all outstanding facility borrowings. The Company was in compliance with the Amended Credit Facility covenants at
December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;EETC Pass Through Certificates, Series&nbsp;2007-1.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;26, 2007, United and Wilmington Trust
Company, as subordination agent and pass through trustee under three pass through trusts newly formed by United (the "Trustee") entered into a note purchase agreement, dated as of June&nbsp;26, 2007
(the "Note Purchase Agreement"). The Note Purchase Agreement provides for the issuance by United of equipment notes (the "Equipment Notes") in the aggregate principal amount of approximately
$694&nbsp;million to finance 13 aircraft owned by United. Ten of these owned aircraft had been financed by pre-existing aircraft mortgages which United repaid in full (approximately
$590&nbsp;million principal amount) with most of the proceeds of the Equipment Notes. The mortgages related to these ten aircraft had been adjusted to fair market value at the adoption of
fresh-start reporting on February&nbsp;1, 2006. The extinguishment of the aircraft mortgages resulted in the recognition of a $22&nbsp;million gain for the unamortized premium, which was accounted
for as a reduction in interest expense in the second quarter of 2007. The remaining three owned aircraft were unencumbered prior to the closing of the Enhanced Equipment Trust Certificates ("EETC")
transaction. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
payment obligations of United under the Equipment Notes are fully and unconditionally guaranteed by UAL. The Class&nbsp;B and Class&nbsp;C certificates are subject to transfer
restrictions. They may </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>119</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=119,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=605327,FOLIO='119',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]GC42801A.;24',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_gc42801_1_120"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(12) Debt Obligations (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>be
sold only to qualified institutional buyers, as defined by Rule&nbsp;144A under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, for so long as they are outstanding. Pursuant to the Note Purchase
Agreement, the Trustee for each pass through trust agreed to purchase Equipment Notes issued under a Trust Indenture and Mortgage (each, an "Indenture" and, collectively, the "Indentures") with
respect to each aircraft financing entered into by United and Wilmington Trust Company, as Mortgagee. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Each
Indenture contemplated the issuance of Equipment Notes in three series: Series&nbsp;A, bearing interest at the rate of 6.636% per annum, Series&nbsp;B, bearing interest at the
rate of 7.336% per annum, and Series&nbsp;C, bearing interest at the rate of six-month LIBOR plus 2.25% per annum, in the aggregate principal amount of approximately $694&nbsp;million
divided between the three series as follows: $485&nbsp;million in the case of Series&nbsp;A Equipment Notes, $107&nbsp;million in the case of Series&nbsp;B Equipment Notes, and
$102&nbsp;million in the case of Series&nbsp;C Equipment Notes. The Equipment Notes were purchased by the Trustee for each pass through trust using the proceeds from the sale of Pass Through
Certificates, Series&nbsp;2007-1A, Pass Through Certificates, Series&nbsp;2007-1B, and Pass Through Certificates, Series&nbsp;2007-1C (collectively, the
"Certificates"). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
on the Equipment Notes is payable semiannually on each January&nbsp;2 and July&nbsp;2, beginning on January&nbsp;2, 2008. Principal payments are scheduled on
January&nbsp;2 and July&nbsp;2 in scheduled years, beginning on January&nbsp;2, 2008. The final payments will be due on July&nbsp;2, 2022, in the case of the Series&nbsp;A Equipment Notes,
July&nbsp;2, 2019, in the case of the Series&nbsp;B Equipment Notes, and July&nbsp;2, 2014, in the case of the Series&nbsp;C Equipment Notes. Maturity of the Equipment Notes may be accelerated
upon the occurrence of certain events of default, including failure by United to make payments under the applicable Indenture when due or to comply with certain covenants, as well as certain
bankruptcy events involving United. The Equipment Notes issued with respect to each of the 13 aircraft are secured by a lien on each such aircraft and are cross-collateralized by the rest of the 13
aircraft financed pursuant to the Note Purchase Agreement. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Distributions
on the Certificates are subject to certain subordination provisions whereby Morgan Stanley Senior Funding,&nbsp;Inc. provided a liquidity facility for each of the
Class&nbsp;A and Class&nbsp;B certificates. The liquidity facilities are expected to provide an amount sufficient to pay up to three semiannual interest payments on the certificates of the related
pass through trust. The Class&nbsp;C certificates do not have the benefit of a liquidity facility. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Denver Special Facilities Airport Revenue Refunding Bonds, Series&nbsp;2007A.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On June&nbsp;28, 2007, the City and County
of Denver issued approximately $270&nbsp;million of Denver International Airport ("DEN") refunding bonds ("Series&nbsp;2007A Bonds"). The Series&nbsp;2007A Bonds are unconditionally guaranteed
by United. The Series&nbsp;2007 A Bonds were issued in two tranches&#151;approximately $170&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of 5.25% discount bonds and $100&nbsp;million aggregate
principal amount of 5.75% premium bonds. The weighted average yield to the 2032 maturity is approximately 5.47%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Series&nbsp;2007A Bonds were issued to refinance United's guaranteed principal of $261&nbsp;million, plus accrued interest and new issuance costs relating to the City and County
of Denver, Colorado Special Facilities Airport Revenue Bonds (United Air Lines Project) Series&nbsp;1992A (the "1992 Bonds") that were issued in 1992 to finance certain facilities at the Denver
International Airport. The 1992 Bonds were due in 2032 unless United elected not to extend its airport facility lease, in which case they were due in 2023. The Series&nbsp;2007A Bonds similarly are
due in 2032 unless United makes a similar </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>120</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_gc42801_1_121"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>election
not to extend its lease. The outstanding bonds and related guarantee are not recorded in the Company's </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Statements of Consolidated Financial
Position</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2007. See Note&nbsp;15, "Commitments, Contingent Liabilities and Uncertainties" for additional information related to these bonds. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;EETC Repurchases.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition, the Company purchased certain of its previously issued and outstanding EETC securities in open
market transactions during 2007. The Company purchased EETC securities, including accrued interest, for $96&nbsp;million and adjusted these securities to a fair value of $91&nbsp;million at
December&nbsp;31, 2007. These EETC securities were issued by third-party pass-through trusts that are not consolidated by the Company. The pass-through trusts' only
investments are equipment notes issued by United. The acquisition of the EETC securities does not legally extinguish the corresponding equipment notes; therefore, the certificates are classified as a
non-current investment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest Rate Swap.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In January&nbsp;2007, the Company terminated the interest rate swap that had been used to hedge the
future interest payments under the original credit facility debt. For further details, see Note&nbsp;14, "Financial Instruments and Risk Management&#151;Interest Rate Swap." </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6% senior notes.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In accordance with the provisions of the 6% senior notes issued in 2006 (see discussion below), UAL elected
to pay interest in kind for one semi-annual interest payment in 2007. Accordingly, the notes have increased by $15&nbsp;million reflecting this in kind interest payment. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>2006 Debt Transactions  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Credit Facility.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On the Effective Date, United obtained a credit facility that provided for a total commitment of up to
$3.0&nbsp;billion that comprised two separate tranches: (i)&nbsp;Tranche&nbsp;A consisted of up to $200&nbsp;million revolving commitment available for Tranche&nbsp;A loans and for standby
letters of credit to be issued in the ordinary course of business of United or one of its subsidiary guarantors; and (ii)&nbsp;Tranche&nbsp;B consisted of a term loan commitment of up to
$2.45&nbsp;billion available at the time of closing and additional delayed draw term loan commitments of up to $350&nbsp;million available upon, among other
things, United's acquiring unencumbered title to some or all of the 14 airframes and related engines that were subject to United's 1997-1 EETC financing. The credit facility would have
matured on February&nbsp;1, 2012 but was amended in February&nbsp;2007, as explained above. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Borrowings
under the credit facility were at a floating interest rate based on either a base rate, or at our option, a LIBOR rate, plus an applicable margin of 2.75% in the case of the
base rate loans and 3.75% in the case of the LIBOR loans. The Tranche&nbsp;B term loan required regularly scheduled semi-annual payments of principal equal to 0.5% of the original
principal amount of the Tranche&nbsp;B term loan. Interest was payable on the last day of the applicable interest period but in no event less than quarterly. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;United's
obligations under the credit facility were unconditionally guaranteed by UAL and certain of the direct and indirect domestic subsidiaries of the Company, other than certain
immaterial subsidiaries (the "Original Guarantors"), and were secured by a security interest in substantially all of the tangible and intangible assets of the Original Guarantors. The obligations
under the credit facility were also secured by a pledge of the capital stock of United and the direct and indirect subsidiaries of UAL Corporation and United, except that a pledge of any
first-tier foreign subsidiary was limited to </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>121</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>65%
of the stock of such subsidiary and such foreign subsidiaries were not required to pledge the stock of their subsidiaries. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Company had outstanding borrowings of $2.8&nbsp;billion of which $2.438&nbsp;billion was subject to an interest rate of 9.12% with the remaining
balance of $348&nbsp;million at 9.125%. In addition, letters of credit were issued under the credit facility as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 in an aggregate amount of $63&nbsp;million subject to an
interest rate of 3.75%. The Company was in compliance with the credit facility covenants at December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Push Down of UAL Securities.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following instruments issued by UAL have been pushed down to United and are reflected as
debt of United as part of fresh-start reporting. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Limited-Subordination Notes.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In July&nbsp;2006, UAL issued $726&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of 4.5% senior
limited-subordination convertible notes to irrevocable trusts established for the benefit of certain of its employees, including employees under collective bargaining agreements. The notes are
unsecured, mature on June&nbsp;30, 2021 and do not require any payment of principal before maturity. Interest is payable semi-annually, in arrears. These notes may be converted into
common stock of Successor UAL at any time after October&nbsp;23, 2006. The conversion price, which was initially $34.84, is subject to adjustment for certain dilutive items and events. Effective
January&nbsp;10, 2008, the conversion price was changed to $32.64 due to UAL's January&nbsp;23, 2008 special distribution to holders of Successor UAL common stock. The notes are junior, in right
of payment upon liquidation, to the Company's obligations under the 5% senior convertible notes and 6% senior notes discussed below. The notes are
callable in cash and/or Successor UAL common stock beginning approximately five years after the issuance date, except that UAL may elect to pay in common stock only if the common stock has traded at
not less than 125% of the conversion price for the 60 consecutive trading days immediately before the redemption date. In addition, on each of June&nbsp;30, 2011 and June&nbsp;30, 2016, holders
have the option to require UAL to repurchase its notes, which UAL may elect to do through the payment of cash or Successor UAL common stock, or a combination of both. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pursuant
to the Plan of Reorganization, the notes were to have been issued at a conversion price of $46.86, which was calculated as 125% of the average closing common stock price for the
60 consecutive trading days following February&nbsp;1, 2006. The Plan of Reorganization also required that the notes bear interest at a rate so that the notes would trade at par upon issuance. Since
the original conversion option was priced significantly out of the money as of the note issuance date of July&nbsp;25, 2006, UAL agreed with employee groups to modify the conversion price to make
the notes more marketable and to provide UAL with a more favorable interest rate. This modification did not alter or eliminate the requirement that an interest rate be selected so that the notes would
trade at par upon issuance. Had UAL not modified the conversion price, the interest rate required to meet the par trading requirement would have been significantly higher than 4.5%. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company accounted for the July&nbsp;25, 2006 modification of debt in accordance with EITF Issue No.&nbsp;96-19, "</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Debtor's Accounting for a
Modification or Exchange of Debt Instruments"</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> and EITF Issue No.&nbsp;05-7, "</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Modifications to Conversion Options Embedded
in Debt Instruments and Related Issues.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>" The Company evaluated the original and modified terms of this debt instrument (including performing a fair valuation of the conversion
feature before and after the modification), and determined that the modification qualified to be accounted for as an extinguishment of debt. As a result, the modified Limited-Subordination Notes were
recorded at fair market value on their date of </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>122</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_gc42801_1_123"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(12) Debt Obligations (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>issuance,
which approximated the book value of the original extinguished notes, and no gain or loss was realized on the extinguishment. The Company had recorded the original obligation to issue the
Limited-Subordination Notes at fair market value upon its emergence from bankruptcy in accordance with fresh-start reporting. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;After
the issuance of the modified notes in July&nbsp;2006, the trusts sold the notes to third parties and remitted the proceeds to the employee beneficiaries. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;5% senior convertible notes.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On the Effective Date, UAL issued these notes to certain holders of the O'Hare municipal bonds
on the Effective Date. The notes are unsecured, have a term of 15&nbsp;years from the date of issuance and do not require any payment of principal before maturity. Interest is payable
semi-annually, in arrears. These 5% senior convertible notes may be converted, at the holder's option, into Successor UAL common stock at any time at an initial conversion price of $46.86.
Effective January&nbsp;10, 2008, the conversion price was adjusted to $43.90 due to the UAL special distribution to holders of Successor UAL common stock on January&nbsp;23, 2008. This conversion
price is subject to adjustment for certain dilutive items and events. These notes are callable, at UAL's option, in
cash or Successor UAL common stock, under certain conditions, beginning five years after the issuance date. In the case of any such redemption, the Company may only redeem these notes with shares of
common stock if Successor UAL common stock has traded at no less than 125% of the conversion price for the 60 consecutive trading days prior to the redemption date. The holders have the option to
require UAL to repurchase their notes on the 5<SUP>th</SUP>&nbsp;and 10<SUP>th</SUP>&nbsp;anniversary of the date of issuance, which UAL may elect to do through the payment of cash, common
stock or a combination of both. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;6% senior notes.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On the Effective Date, UAL issued these notes to the PBGC. These notes are unsecured, mature 25&nbsp;years
from the issuance date and do not require any payment of principal before maturity. Interest is payable semi-annually, in arrears. Interest may be paid with cash, in kind notes or
Successor UAL common stock through 2011 and thereafter in cash. These notes are callable at any time at 100% of par value, and can be redeemed with either cash or Successor UAL common stock at UAL's
option. Upon a change in control or other event as defined in the agreement, UAL has an obligation to redeem the notes. In the case of such mandatory redemption, UAL may elect to redeem the notes in
cash, in shares of Successor UAL common stock or a combination thereof. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Contingent Senior Unsecured Notes.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In addition to the debt issued as noted above, UAL is obligated to issue to the PBGC 8%
senior unsecured notes with an aggregate $500&nbsp;million principal amount in up to eight equal tranches of $62.5&nbsp;million (with no more than two tranches issued on a single date) upon the
occurrence of certain financial triggering events. Any required tranche will be issued no later than 45&nbsp;days following the end of any fiscal year in which there is an issuance trigger event,
starting with the fiscal year ending December&nbsp;31, 2009 and ending with the fiscal year ending December&nbsp;31, 2017. An issuance trigger event occurs when, among other things, the Company's
EBITDAR exceeds $3.5&nbsp;billion over the prior twelve months ending June&nbsp;30 or December&nbsp;31 of any applicable fiscal year, beginning with the fiscal year ending December&nbsp;31,
2009. However, if the issuance of a tranche would cause a default under any other securities then existing, UAL may satisfy its obligations with respect to such tranche by issuing Successor UAL common
stock having a market value equal to $62.5&nbsp;million. Each issued tranche will mature 15&nbsp;years from its respective issuance date, with interest payable in cash in semi-annual
installments, and will be callable at any time at 100% of par value, plus accrued and unpaid interest. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2007, UAL's contractual principal payments under then-outstanding long-term debt agreements in each of the next
five calendar years are as follows: 2008&#151;$678&nbsp;million; 2009&#151;$737million; 2010&#151;$918&nbsp;million; 2011&#151;$824&nbsp;million;
2012&#151;$385&nbsp;million and thereafter&#151;$3,802&nbsp;million. At December&nbsp;31, 2007, United's contractual principal payments under then-outstanding
long-term debt agreements in each of the next five calendar years are as follows: 2008&#151;$678&nbsp;million; 2009&#151;$736&nbsp;million;
2010&#151;$917&nbsp;million; 2011&#151;$824&nbsp;million; 2012&#151;$385&nbsp;million and thereafter&#151;$3,801&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to the Amended Credit Facility collateral described above, aircraft having an aggregate book value of $5.6&nbsp;billion at December&nbsp;31, 2007 were pledged as security
under various loan agreements. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, 113 aircraft with a net book value of $2.0&nbsp;billion were unencumbered. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(13) UAL Preferred Stock  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following instrument has been pushed down to United and is reflected on United's books as part of fresh-start reporting. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;UAL
is authorized to issue 250&nbsp;million shares of preferred stock (without par value), 5&nbsp;million shares of 2% convertible preferred stock (par value $0.01 per share) and two
shares of junior preferred stock (par value $0.01 per share). </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
2% convertible preferred stock was issued to the PBGC on the Effective Date. The shares were issued at a liquidation value of $100 per share, convertible at any time following the
second anniversary of the issuance date into common stock of Successor UAL at an initial conversion price of $46.86 per common share; with dividends payable in kind semi-annually (in the
form of increases to the liquidation value of the issued and outstanding shares). The preferred stock ranks pari passu with all current and future UAL or United preferred stock and is redeemable at
any time at the then-current liquidation value (plus accrued and unpaid dividends) at the option of the issuer. The preferred stock is mandatorily convertible 15&nbsp;years from the date
of issuance. Upon a fundamental change or a change in ownership as defined in UAL's restated certificate of incorporation, holders of shares of the preferred stock are also entitled to receive payment
equal to the amount they would receive in an actual liquidation of UAL. At December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, 5&nbsp;million shares of 2% convertible preferred stock were outstanding with an
aggregate liquidation value of $519&nbsp;million and $509&nbsp;million, respectively, which includes $19&nbsp;million and $9&nbsp;million, respectively, of accrued and paid in kind dividends.
At December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, the carrying value of the 2% convertible preferred stock was $371&nbsp;million and $361&nbsp;million, respectively. The carrying value includes
$19&nbsp;million and $9&nbsp;million of accrued and paid in kind dividends at December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. In addition, the two shares of junior preferred stock were issued in
2006. In February&nbsp;2008, 1.0&nbsp;million preferred shares were converted into approximately 2.2&nbsp;million common shares. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(14) Financial Instruments and Risk Management  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Instruments designated as cash flow hedges are accounted for under Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;133, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting
for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> ("SFAS&nbsp;133"), as long as the hedge is highly effective and the underlying transaction is probable. If both factors are
present, the effective portion of the changes in fair value of these contracts is recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) until earnings are affected by the cash flows being </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>124</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=124,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=928940,FOLIO='124',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]GE42801A.;20',USER='MWEINST',CD='28-FEB-2008;11:17' -->
<A NAME="page_ge42801_1_125"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(14) Financial Instruments and Risk Management (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>hedged.
To the extent that the designated cash flow hedges are ineffective, gain or loss is recognized currently in earnings. The Company offsets the fair value of derivative instruments executed with
the same counterparty when netting agreements exist. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Instruments
classified as economic hedges do not qualify for hedge accounting under SFAS&nbsp;133. Under this classification all changes in the fair value of these contracts are
recorded currently in income, with the offset to either current assets or liabilities each reporting period. Economic fuel hedge gains and losses are classified as part of aircraft fuel expense, and
foreign currency hedge gains and losses are classified as part of nonoperating income. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Aircraft Fuel Hedges.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has a risk management strategy to hedge a portion of its price risk related to projected jet fuel requirements primarily through collar options. The
collars involve the purchase of fuel call options with the simultaneous sale of fuel put options with identical expiration dates. In the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and the eleven months ended
December&nbsp;31, 2006, the Successor Company entered into and settled various derivative positions for its mainline operations that were classified as economic hedges. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company's Mainline fuel expense included income of $83&nbsp;million from net gains on economic hedges. The net hedge gains recorded in
2007 included $20&nbsp;million of unrealized mark-to-market gains for contracts settling after December&nbsp;31, 2007. In the eleven months ended December&nbsp;31, 2006,
the Successor Company recognized
a net loss of $26&nbsp;million which included a $24&nbsp;million realized loss on settled contracts and $2&nbsp;million of unrealized mark-to-market losses for contracts
settling after December&nbsp;31, 2006, all of which were classified as mainline fuel expense in the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Statements of Consolidated Operations</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. In 2005,
the Predecessor Company recognized income of $40&nbsp;million in non-operating income primarily due to non-designated hedges. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company had hedged 13% of forecasted first quarter 2008 fuel consumption of which 82% is through three-way collars with upside protection,
on a weighted-average basis, beginning from $90 per barrel and capped at $100 per barrel with payment obligations, on a weighted-average basis, beginning if crude oil drops below $85 per barrel. The
remaining 18% is hedged through collars with upside protection beginning, on a weighted-average basis, at a crude oil equivalent price of $101 per barrel with payment obligations, on a weighted-
average basis, beginning if crude oil drops below $91 per barrel. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company had hedged 13% of forecasted fuel consumption for 2008, of which 67% is through three-way collars with upside protection, on a
weighted-average basis, beginning from $87 per barrel and capped at $100 per barrel with payment obligations, on a weighted-average basis, beginning if crude oil drops below $81 per barrel. The
remaining 33% is hedged through collars with upside protection beginning, on a weighted-average, at a crude oil equivalent price of $94 per barrel with payment obligations, on a weighted-average,
beginning if crude oil drops below $81 per barrel. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Interest Rate Swap.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;From time to time, the Company uses interest rate swap agreements to effectively limit exposure to interest rate movements within the parameters of the Company's
interest rate hedging policy. In </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>125</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=125,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=426910,FOLIO='125',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]GE42801A.;20',USER='MWEINST',CD='28-FEB-2008;11:17' -->
<A NAME="page_ge42801_1_126"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(14) Financial Instruments and Risk Management (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>February&nbsp;2006,
the Successor Company entered into an interest rate swap with an initial notional amount of $2.45&nbsp;billion that would have decreased to $1.8&nbsp;billion over the term of
the swap. The swap would have expired in February&nbsp;2012 and required that the Company pay a fixed rate of 5.14% and receive a floating rate based on the three-month LIBOR rate. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company initially applied hedge accounting for the swap but subsequently discontinued hedge accounting in 2006 as the Company determined that it was no longer probable that a portion
of the forecasted cash flows hedged by the swap would occur, in light of the Company's developing plans to retire a portion of the credit facility in advance of scheduled maturities. Any gains and
losses related to interest rate swap agreements, if any, that are included in earnings are classified as interest expense. In January&nbsp;2007, the Company terminated the interest rate swap that
had been used to hedge the future interest payments under the original credit facility. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Foreign Currency Derivatives.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2007, the Company began hedging a portion of its remaining 2007 foreign currency risk exposure using foreign currency forward contracts. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company hedged a portion of its expected foreign currency cash flows in the Australian dollar, Canadian dollar, British pound, European Euro and Japanese yen. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2007, the notional amount of these foreign currencies hedged with the forward contracts in U.S. dollars terms was approximately $346&nbsp;million. These contracts expire at
various dates through December&nbsp;2008. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, there were no material gains or losses from these derivative positions. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Fair Value of Financial Instruments.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following methods and assumptions were used to estimate the fair value of each class of financial instruments for which such estimates can be made: </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Cash and Cash Equivalents, Restricted Cash and Short-term Investments.  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The carrying amounts approximate fair value because of the short-term maturity of these investments. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Derivative Financial Instruments.  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Market prices used to determine fair value fuel-related and foreign currency derivatives are primarily based on prices obtained from counterparties or
broker-dealers. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>Preferred Stock and Long-Term Debt.  </I></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The fair value is based on the quoted market prices for the same or similar issues, discounted cash flow models using appropriate market rates and the
Black-Scholes model to value conversion rights in UAL's convertible preferred stock and debt instruments. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table presents the carrying amounts and estimated fair values of the Company's financial instruments at December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006. Amounts shown below are
applicable to both UAL and United except that long-term debt is presented on a UAL consolidated basis, which is approximately $3&nbsp;million and $4&nbsp;million higher than both the
carrying value and fair value of United's </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>126</FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(15) Commitments, Contingent Liabilities and Uncertainties  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;General Guarantees and Indemnifications.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the normal course of business, the Company enters into
numerous real estate leasing and aircraft financing arrangements that have various guarantees included in the contracts. These guarantees are primarily in the form of indemnities. In both leasing and
financing transactions, the Company typically indemnifies the lessors, and any tax/financing parties, against tort liabilities that arise out of the use, occupancy, operation or maintenance of the
leased premises or financed aircraft. Currently, the Company believes that any future payments required under these guarantees or indemnities would be immaterial, as most tort liabilities and related
indemnities are covered by insurance (subject to deductibles). Additionally, certain leased premises such as fueling stations or storage facilities include indemnities of such parties for any
environmental liability that may arise out of or relate to the use of the leased premises. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Legal and Environmental Contingencies.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has certain contingencies resulting from
litigation and claims (including environmental issues) incident to the ordinary course of business. Management believes, after considering a number of factors, including (but not limited to) the
information currently available, the views of legal counsel, the nature of contingencies to which the Company is subject and prior experience, that the ultimate disposition of these contingencies will
not materially affect the Company's consolidated financial position or results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company records liabilities for legal and environmental claims when a loss is probable and reasonably estimatable. These amounts are recorded based on the Company's assessments of
the likelihood of their eventual disposition. The amounts of these liabilities could increase or decrease in the near term, based on revisions to estimates relating to the various claims. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company anticipates that if ultimately found liable, its damages from claims arising from the events of September&nbsp;11, 2001 could be significant; however, the Company believes
that, under the Air Transportation Safety and System Stabilization Act of 2001, its liability will be limited to its insurance coverage. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company is also currently analyzing whether any potential liability may result from air cargo/passenger surcharge cartel investigations following the receipt of a Statement of
Objections that the European Commission (the "Commission") issued to 26 carriers on December&nbsp;18, 2007. The Statement of Objections sets out evidence related to the utilization of fuel and
security surcharges and exchange of pricing information that the Commission views as supporting the conclusion that an illegal price- </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>127</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=127,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=218186,FOLIO='127',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]GE42801A.;20',USER='MWEINST',CD='28-FEB-2008;11:17' -->
<A NAME="page_ge42801_1_128"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(15) Commitments, Contingent Liabilities and Uncertainties (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>fixing
cartel had been in operation in the air cargo transportation industry. United received a copy of the Statement of Objections and is currently evaluating the Commission's evidence related to the
Company and its personnel. United is cooperating with the Commission's investigation. United intends to defend itself vigorously against these charges in its formal response to the Commission and in
the European Court of Justice if necessary. The Company's evaluation of this matter is still in the early stages, and based upon the information currently available no reserve for potential liability
has been recorded as of December&nbsp;31, 2007. However, penalties for violation of European competition laws can be substantial and a finding that the Company engaged in improper activity could
have a material adverse impact on our consolidated financial position and results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Contingent Senior Unsecured Notes.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;UAL is obligated to issue up to $500&nbsp;million of 8% senior
unsecured notes to the PBGC in up to eight equal tranches of $62.5&nbsp;million upon the occurrence of certain financial triggering events. Beginning with fiscal year ending December&nbsp;31, 2009
and ending with fiscal year December&nbsp;31, 2017, a triggering event may occur when, among other things, the Company's EBITDAR exceeds $3.5&nbsp;billion over a prior twelve month period. In
certain circumstances, UAL common stock may be issued in lieu of issuance of the notes. See Note&nbsp;12, "Debt Obligations" for further information. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commitments.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At December&nbsp;31, 2007, future commitments for the purchase of property and
equipment, principally aircraft, approximated $2.9&nbsp;billion, after deducting advance payments. The Company's current commitments are primarily for the purchase of, in the aggregate, 42 A319 and
A320 aircraft. In January&nbsp;2006, United reached an agreement with the airframe manufacturer to delay, with the right to cancel these future orders. Such action could cause the forfeiture of
$91&nbsp;million of advance payments if United does not take future delivery of these aircraft. The Company also reached an agreement with the engine manufacturer eliminating all provisions
pertaining to firm commitments and support for future Airbus aircraft. While this permits future negotiations on engine pricing with any engine manufacturer, restructured aircraft manufacturer
commitments have assumed that aircraft will be delivered with installed engines at list price. The Company's current commitments would require the payment of an estimated $0.4&nbsp;billion in 2008,
$0.3&nbsp;billion for the combined years of 2009 and 2010, $0.7&nbsp;billion for the combined years of 2011 and 2012 and $1.5&nbsp;billion thereafter. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Guarantees and Off-Balance Sheet Financing.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fuel Consortia.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company participates in numerous fuel consortia with other carriers at major airports to reduce the costs
of fuel distribution and storage. Interline agreements govern the rights and responsibilities of the consortia members and provide for the allocation of the overall costs to operate the consortia
based on usage. The consortium (and in limited cases, the participating carriers) have entered into long-term agreements to lease certain airport fuel storage and distribution facilities
that are typically financed through tax-exempt bonds (either special facilities lease revenue bonds or general airport revenue bonds), issued by various local municipalities. In general,
each consortium lease agreement requires the consortium to make lease payments in amounts sufficient to pay the maturing principal and interest payments on the bonds. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007,
approximately $890&nbsp;million principal amount of such bonds were secured by significant fuel facility leases in which United participates, as to which United and each of the signatory airlines
has provided indirect guarantees of the debt. United's contingent exposure is approximately $195&nbsp;million principal amount of such bonds based on its recent consortia participation. The
Company's contingent exposure could increase if the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>128</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=128,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=228132,FOLIO='128',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]GE42801A.;20',USER='MWEINST',CD='28-FEB-2008;11:17' -->
<A NAME="page_ge42801_1_129"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(15) Commitments, Contingent Liabilities and Uncertainties (Continued) </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>participation
of other carriers decreases. The guarantees will expire when the tax-exempt bonds are paid in full, which ranges from 2010 to 2028. The Company did not record a liability at
the time these indirect guarantees were made. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Municipal Bond Guarantees.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company has entered into long-term agreements to lease certain airport and
maintenance facilities that are financed through tax-exempt municipal bonds. These bonds were issued by various local municipalities to build or improve airport and maintenance facilities.
Under these lease agreements, United is required to make rental payments in amounts sufficient to pay the maturing principal and interest payments on the bonds. However, as a result of the bankruptcy
filing, United was not permitted to make payments on unsecured pre-petition debt. The Company was advised that these municipal bonds may be unsecured (or in certain instances, partially
secured). In 2006, as a result of the final Bankruptcy Court decisions, certain leases (SFO and LAX) were considered to be financings resulting in the Company's guarantees being discharged in
bankruptcy. The DEN lease related to the 1992 bonds, as discussed in Note&nbsp;12, "Debt Obligations," was not rejected. The Company has guaranteed interest and principal payments on
$270&nbsp;million of the DEN bonds, which were originally issued in 1992, redeemed and reissued in 2007 and are due in 2032 unless the Company elects not to extend its lease in which case the bonds
are due in 2023. The outstanding bonds and related guarantee are not recorded in the Company's </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Statements of Consolidated Financial Position</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> at
December&nbsp;31, 2007 or 2006. The related lease agreement is recorded on a straight-line basis resulting in ratable accrual of the final $270&nbsp;million lease obligation over the
lease term. The annual lease payments through 2023 and the final payment for the principal amount of the bonds are included in the future operating lease payments disclosed in Non-aircraft
lease payments in Note&nbsp;16, "Lease Obligations." There remains an issue as to whether the LAX and SFO bondholders have a secured interest in certain of the Company's leasehold improvements. The
Company has accrued an amount which it estimates is
probable to be approved by the Bankruptcy Court for these secured interests. See Note&nbsp;1, "Voluntary Reorganization Under Chapter&nbsp;11&#151;Significant Matters Remaining to be
Resolved in Chapter&nbsp;11 Cases," for a discussion of ongoing litigation with respect to certain of these obligations. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Collective Bargaining Agreements.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Approximately 81% of United's employees are represented by various U.S. labor organizations. During 2005, United reached new agreements with its labor unions for
new collective bargaining agreements which became effective in January&nbsp;2005. These agreements are not amendable until January&nbsp;2010. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(16) Lease Obligations  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Company leases aircraft, airport passenger terminal space, aircraft hangars and related maintenance facilities, cargo terminals, other airport facilities,
other commercial real estate, office and computer equipment and vehicles. As allowed under Section&nbsp;365 of the Bankruptcy Code, during its reorganization the Company assumed, assumed and
assigned, or rejected certain executory contracts and unexpired leases, including leases of real property, aircraft and aircraft engines, subject to the approval of the Bankruptcy Court and certain
other conditions. During bankruptcy, the Company also entered into numerous aircraft financing term sheets with financiers, some of which were implemented before the Effective Date, and others of
which were implemented on the Effective Date. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>129</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->

 </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies  </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued)  </I></B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(16) Lease Obligations (Continued)  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with fresh-start reporting requirements, aircraft operating leases were adjusted to fair value and a net deferred asset of $263&nbsp;million was
recorded in the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Statement of Consolidated Financial Position</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> on the Effective Date, representing the net present value of the differences between stated
lease rates in agreed term sheets and the fair market lease rates for similar aircraft. These deferred amounts are amortized on a straight-line basis as an adjustment to aircraft rent
expense over the individual applicable remaining lease terms, generally from one to 17&nbsp;years. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
December&nbsp;31, 2007, the Company's leased aircraft, scheduled future minimum lease payments under capital leases (substantially all of which are for aircraft) and operating
leases having initial or remaining noncancelable lease terms of more than one year were as follows: </FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="120">
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(a)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Amounts
apply to both UAL and United except that United leases one aircraft from UAL, resulting in total United mainline aircraft operating lease payments of $2,523&nbsp;million.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(b)</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Aircraft
lease obligations are for 44 Mainline and 28 United Express aircraft. Includes non-aircraft capital lease payments aggregating $19&nbsp;million in years 2008
through 2011, and United Express capital lease obligations of $13&nbsp;million in 2008, $11&nbsp;million in 2009, $5&nbsp;million each in years 2010, 2011 and 2012 and $4&nbsp;million
thereafter. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Aircraft operating leases have initial terms of 1 to 26&nbsp;years, with expiration dates ranging from 2008 through 2024. The Company has
facility operating leases that extend to 2030. Under the terms of most leases, the Company has the right to purchase the aircraft at the end of the lease term, in some cases at fair market value and
in others, at fair market value or a percentage of cost. See Note&nbsp;2(j), "Summary of Significant Accounting Policies&#151;United Express" for additional information related to United
Express contracts. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>130</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=130,EFW="2182991",CP="UAL CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=54144,FOLIO='130',FILE='DISK125:[08ZAE1.08ZAE42801]GG42801A.;29',USER='CHANSON',CD='28-FEB-2008;08:42' -->
<A NAME="page_gg42801_1_131"> </A>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>UAL Corporation and Subsidiary Companies </B></FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Combined Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (Continued) </I></B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>(16) Lease Obligations (Continued) </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain
of the Company's aircraft lease transactions contain provisions such as put options giving the lessor the right to require us to purchase the aircraft at lease termination for a
certain amount resulting in residual value guarantees. Leases containing this or similar provisions are recorded as capital leases on the balance sheet and, accordingly, all residual value guarantee
amounts contained in the Company's aircraft leases are fully reflected as capital lease obligations in the </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Statements of Consolidated Financial
Position</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
connection with certain euro-denominated aircraft financings accounted for as capital leases, United had on deposit in certain banks at December&nbsp;31, 2007 an
aggregate 338&nbsp;million euros ($497&nbsp;million) and $19&nbsp;million in U.S. denominated deposits, and had pledged an irrevocable security interest in such deposits to certain of the
aircraft lessors. These deposits will be used to repay an equivalent amount of recorded capital lease obligations, and are classified as aircraft lease deposits in the </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Statements of Consolidated Financial
Position</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Amounts
charged to rent expense, net of minor amounts of sublease rentals, were $934&nbsp;million and $936&nbsp;million for UAL and United, respectively, for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2007; $833&nbsp;million and $834&nbsp;million for UAL and United, respectively, for the eleven months ended December&nbsp;31, 2006; $76&nbsp;million for both UAL and United
for the month ended January&nbsp;31, 2006; and $1.0&nbsp;billion for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 for both UAL and United. Included in Regional affiliates expense in the </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Statements of Consolidated
Operations</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> were operating rents for United Express aircraft of $425&nbsp;million and $403&nbsp;million for the Successor
Company for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and the eleven
months ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, respectively; and $35&nbsp;million and $449&nbsp;million for the month ended January&nbsp;31, 2006 and the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005,
respectively, for the Predecessor Company. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Company has various operating leases for 121 aircraft in which the lessors are trusts established specifically to purchase, finance and lease aircraft to United. These leasing
entities meet the criteria for VIEs; however, the Company does not hold a significant variable interest in, and is not considered the primary beneficiary of the leasing entities since the lease terms
are consistent with market terms at the inception of the lease and do not include a residual value guarantee, fixed-price purchase option or similar feature that obligates us to absorb decreases in
value, or entitles the Company to participate in increases in the value of the financed aircraft. In addition, of the Company's total aircraft operating leases only 10 of these aircraft leases allow
the Company to purchase the aircraft at other than fair market value; these leases have fixed price buy out options specified in the lease agreements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>131</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
